questions.fact: AI models like GPT-4 are trained on large datasets of text from the internet and books.
questions.myth: AI models like GPT-4 have access to the live internet and can browse websites in real-time.

questions.fact: Generative AI can create new content like text, images, and music based on patterns it learned during training.
questions.myth: Generative AI creates truly original content that has never existed before, completely independent of its training data.

questions.fact: AI image generators like DALL-E and Midjourney create images based on text descriptions.
questions.myth: AI image generators take photos of real objects and just modify them slightly.

questions.fact: Large Language Models (LLMs) predict the next word in a sequence based on probability.
questions.myth: Large Language Models (LLMs) understand the meaning of words the same way humans do.

questions.fact: AI models can make mistakes and generate incorrect information sometimes called 'hallucinations'.
questions.myth: AI models always provide 100% accurate information because they're programmed to be error-free.

questions.fact: Prompt engineering is the practice of crafting effective inputs to get better outputs from AI models.
questions.myth: Prompt engineering is the process of physically building AI hardware components.

questions.fact: AI models can be fine-tuned on specific datasets to improve performance for particular tasks.
questions.myth: Once an AI model is created, its capabilities are fixed and cannot be modified or improved.

questions.fact: Generative AI models have parameters that can number in the billions or trillions.
questions.myth: The more parameters an AI model has, the slower it always becomes at generating responses.

questions.fact: AI can assist with creative tasks but works best when collaborating with human creativity.
questions.myth: AI will soon replace all creative professionals like artists, writers, and musicians.

questions.fact: Multimodal AI models can process and generate different types of content like text, images, and audio.
questions.myth: Each AI model can only work with one type of data - either text, images, or audio, but never multiple types.

questions.fact: AI models have a 'context window' that limits how much information they can consider at once.
questions.myth: AI models have unlimited memory and can remember everything from all previous conversations forever.

questions.fact: Transfer learning allows AI models to apply knowledge from one task to help with another task.
questions.myth: Each AI model must be built from scratch for every new task with no ability to transfer knowledge.

questions.fact: AI models reflect biases present in their training data, which researchers work to identify and mitigate.
questions.myth: AI is completely objective and free from any human biases because it's just math and code.

questions.fact: Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF) helps align AI models with human preferences.
questions.myth: AI models learn entirely on their own with no human input after their initial creation.

questions.fact: AI models consume significant energy during training, but inference (using the trained model) requires less.
questions.myth: AI has no environmental impact because it's all digital and doesn't use physical resources.

questions.fact: AI can generate code to help programmers but often requires human review and modification.
questions.myth: AI can build complete, complex software applications without any human intervention.

questions.fact: Generative AI models can be used to create synthetic data for training other AI systems.
questions.myth: Using AI to generate training data for other AI systems always creates perfect, bias-free datasets.

questions.fact: Foundation models are large AI systems trained on broad data that can be adapted for specific applications.
questions.myth: Each AI application requires its own completely separate model trained from scratch.

questions.fact: AI systems can be designed with guardrails to prevent harmful outputs.
questions.myth: AI systems either have complete freedom or no freedom - there's no middle ground for safety measures.

questions.fact: Generative AI models can sometimes produce outputs that appear to violate copyright or contain private information.
questions.myth: AI-generated content is always completely original and can never contain elements from copyrighted works.

questions.fact: AI models can be distilled into smaller versions that retain much of their capability but run more efficiently.
questions.myth: The only way to improve AI performance is to make models larger with more parameters.

questions.fact: Generative AI can help with brainstorming by suggesting ideas humans might not think of.
questions.myth: AI creativity is completely random and produces mostly unusable suggestions.

questions.fact: AI models can be evaluated using benchmarks to measure their performance on specific tasks.
questions.myth: There's no way to measure or compare the capabilities of different AI models objectively.

questions.fact: AI can translate between languages but may miss cultural nuances and context-specific meanings.
questions.myth: AI translation is perfect and has completely eliminated the need for human translators.

questions.fact: Generative AI models can be fine-tuned to follow specific style guidelines or brand voices.
questions.myth: AI-generated content always sounds robotic and can never match a specific human writing style.

questions.fact: AI models can be deployed on various hardware from cloud servers to mobile devices.
questions.myth: AI can only run on supercomputers due to its complexity and processing requirements.

questions.fact: AI can help analyze large datasets to find patterns humans might miss.
questions.myth: AI analysis of data is just a fancy term for basic statistical methods that have existed for decades.

questions.fact: AI models can be combined with human expertise to create hybrid workflows.
questions.myth: AI implementation is an all-or-nothing approach where humans must be completely removed from the process.

questions.fact: Different AI models have different strengths and are suited for different types of tasks.
questions.myth: There is one 'best' AI model that outperforms all others on every possible task.

questions.fact: AI models can be personalized to better serve individual users' needs and preferences.
questions.myth: All users receive identical outputs from AI systems with no possibility for personalization.
